questions.text: All of the following statements about surgical management of gastric lymphomas are true except:

options.label: A
options.text: Stage I gastric lymphomas (small lesions confined to the stomach wall) can be cured completely with surgical therapy alone.

options.label: B
options.text: Extensive gastric lymphomas that initially are treated with radiation and/or chemotherapy occasionally perforate during treatment and require secondary resection.

options.label: C
options.text: Patients explored with a presumptive diagnosis of gastric lymphoma should undergo an attempt at curative resection when this is safe and feasible.

options.label: D
options.text: Without a preoperative diagnosis resection for gastric mass should not be attempted unless lymphoma can be excluded.

questions.correct_answer: D. Without a preoperative diagnosis resection for gastric mass should not be attempted unless lymphoma can be excluded.

questions.text: Local anaesthetics alter nerve function by their action on sodium channels.

options.label: A
options.text: local anesthetics binding results in cessation of the depolarization by preventing sodium ions entering the cell

options.label: B
options.text: Sodium channels in the resting state have a high affinity for local anaesthetic

options.label: C
options.text: The binding of bupivacaine to the sodium channel is irreversible

options.label: D
options.text: Local anaesthetics bind directly to the extracellular portion of the sodium channel to exert the effect

questions.correct_answer: A. local anesthetics binding results in cessation of the depolarization by preventing sodium ions entering the cell

During the delivery, it is necessary to cut an episiotomy. The tear extends through the sphincter of the rectum, but the rectal mucosa is intact. How would you classify this type of episiotomy?
questions.explanation:
References:

  • ↳ In a second-degree episiotomy , the underlying subcutaneous tissue is also involved, but not the rectal sphincter or rectal mucosa .
  • ↳ second-degree episiotomy
  • ↳ sphincter or rectal mucosa
  • ↳ In a third- degree tear, the rectal sphincter is affected . A fourth-degree episiotomy involves a tear that extends into the rectal mucosa
  • ↳ degree tear, the rectal sphincter is affected
